results.title: Singapore: a study of a port
results.creator_credit: Brian Salt, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: Singapore is taken as an example of a city which exists by reason of its function as a port. Opening scenes introduce the harbour, Singapore River and statue of the founder, Sir Stamford Raffles. Maps illustrate Singapore’s position of shipping routes and explains the reasons which lead Raffles to establish a port there. The scope and nature of port activities are illustrated. Local industries and resources, nature of the hinterland, malaria control and climate are dealt with. By means of maps and actual scenes, the nature of the different quaters of the city is examined in detail.

results.title: Singapore dollars
results.creator_credit: Edward Dunstan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Edward Dunstan served in the Australian Navy for 20 years, spending a significant part of that time in Singapore. While he enjoyed his time there, Dunstan also has some bad memories, not least of all was how he was received by his fellow Australians on his return. However, these experiences have encouraged him to help others through his work at the RSL.

results.title: Sing Out for Wales
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
The Royal National Eisteddfod is an annual celebration of the Welsh language and culture, particularly as expressed in mass choirs and poetry. The miserable weather conditions of this particular Eisteddfod do little to dampen the enthusiasm of the participants as they gather to elect the prize-winning bard of the year.

results.title: Sing of the border
results.creator_credit: Tony Thompson, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: The songs of the Scottish border country are more than just folk songs. They are the history of a people. Families fought for power along the border, and the ballads have preserved their names and deeds. Although battles have passed, the country and the pattern of life remain much the same today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Thompson, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films

results.title: Sing and be happy with Jane Pickens
results.brief_description: A musical sing-along with Jane Pickens (with audience participation and bouncing ball). Songs include: ‘I’ll be walking with my honey’, ‘I never knew’, and ‘I’ll see you in my dreams’.

results.title: Sing a little
results.brief_description: Illustrates a Canadian Broadcasting Company radio session of which Allan Mills is compere. Three songs are presented: “The Farmer’s cursed wife” whom even the devil wouldn’t keep; “Barbara Allen”; and “Jack the sailor” who was swallowed by a whale. Animated puppets enact the story told by each song.

results.title: Sine Curve
results.creator_credit: Donald Batchelor and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Discusses the sine funtion. Illustrates familiar periodic motions and uses models to analyse the nature of a wave motion and to show how a sine curve can be drawn. From the series “Visions in mathematics”.

results.title: Since I Left You – The Avalanches
results.brief_description: Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling, The Avalanches’ ‘Since I Left You’ manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.

constellations_primary.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_primary.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

results.description: It seems fitting that for a band with such an unusual musical reputation like The Avalanches, the accompanying visuals to ‘Since I Left You’ would be so unique as well. Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling from the Blue Source art collective, it manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.
description_for_label: It seems fitting that for a band with such an unusual musical reputation like The Avalanches, the accompanying visuals to ‘Since I Left You’ would be so unique as well. Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling from the Blue Source art collective, it manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.
